This should work in all files where CSS is embedded and netbeans "knows" that it is CSS. The idea is, that property wrapping is only enabled inside rule blocks. Property definitions in style attributes will not be wrapped.

I created a test build, which can be found here:

https://doppel-helix.eu/NetBeans-dev-dev-8cd0778dd680165cd766e932a71fb2c00d9f864c-release.zip

That is current master (cca3859c55647e199a72bd959eedcb9ade930160) merged with the head of this PR.
Looks ok minus one removal to be on 12.5 if you want
still no answer changing to milestone 12.6
this PR is a bit old but maybe @jlahoda may say it's ok to merge for 12.5.

Thx, it is working just fine in a CSS and SCSS file, just inside of an html file it looks like so:

Before:
```html
<style>body{color:red;}</style>
```

After:
```html
<style>body{
            color:red
        }</style>
```

But I would expect smth like this:
```html
<style>
body{
    color:red
}
</style>
```

And also, no spaces where added but as you said, it is just a minimal one so having body{ instead of body { is better than nothing.

An Idea for later because of using LSP and already node and typescript etc. doesn't it make sense for a later version to use things that are already there and where used for such things instead of using Java? Just an idea. I mean using prettier where you just have a config make much more sense as to create it again by your own.
yess green after 3 rerun
@ebarboni thanks for the perseverance! :smile:

@Chris2011  Thanks for checking. Yes handling of embedded source is not optimal, but I have to see if it is possible to discern the cases:

- CSS/SCSS/LESS stand alone
- CSS in style tag
- CSS in style attribute
- CSS recognized in ID attributes
- CSS in style tags, that contain other embedded code sequences (PHP)

The current state should be robust enough to work in any of these situations, but especially the last case makes it difficult to handle.

For the usage of node based tools: From my POV a straight no. NetBeans has a single hard dependency on an installed node when it comes to the typescript support. In that case I can live with it, as you'll need node anyway to do anything relevant with typescript sources anyway. The same is not true for CSS. CSS is used in JSF, JSP and JavaFX and for these groups there is zero reason to install a secondary tool, just to do some CSS formatting.
Testing it now.

What is the use case for this feature?

It might be better to make this work with the regular Copy action--i.e. if you copy a node that happens to be a class, and try to paste it into a text editor, it will paste the fully qualified class name. Similarly, copying a node that is a file (but not a Java class) might paste the file path. (Adding new actions for very workflow-specific features makes menus very long...)
I recommend discussing your approach to solving an issue on the mailing list before implementing it.
This plugin basicly implements this: https://github.com/Chris2011/nb-copy-fqn
If we think this is the right way to implement this, let’s merge, after taking a look at the code, but isn’t @eirikbakke’s comment valid that this should be in the standard Copy action?

@eirikbakke 

> What is the use case for this feature?

Everytime I want to share the exact location of a class I'll need a fully qualified class name. Like Spring xml configuration, referencing classes exact location for Jira Tickets, ...

> It might be better to make this work with the regular Copy action--i.e. if you copy a node that happens to be a class, and try to paste it into a text editor, it will paste the fully qualified class name.

That might be an alternative. Tbh I oriented the implementation to the plugin @matthiasblaesing and eclipse. Only downside I'd see it would a little bit slower to access with a mouse than with a context menu in navigator and code editor.

> Adding new actions for very workflow-specific features makes menus very long...

I wonder if it really a workflow specific feature. I agree that before adding items to these kind of menus that should be part of a discussion.

@geertjanw 

> I recommend discussing your approach to solving an issue on the mailing list before implementing it.

Yeah you might be right. Acutally I wanted to get some handy on the platform in preparation of trying to implement `mvnd`.

@matthiasblaesing 

> This plugin basicly implements this: https://github.com/Chris2011/nb-copy-fqn

You're right. It's a reimplementation since the plugin does not work with recent NetBeans version and with quite none dependencies.
Squashed before merging.

I would be somewhat careful with including this change in 12.5: while the negative cache is (in theory harmless), the PR disables loading classes through classloaders that SHOULD be OK as well, but might surface in unexpected ways. Especially I wouldn't like to break editing in Gradle scripts (which also use Groovy parsing).

@jtulach, @dbalek - opinions ?
There is at least a month till release 12.5. Plenty of time to fix problems, if they are reported.
Good. Travis failures seem unrelated to the PR. Merging.

I completely agree this function is pretty helpful. I used mentioned plugin too. I need it for adding ignored classes for Spotbugs etc. I think that copy on a node is not a good idea because it is not straightforward. What if you want to paste only classname, filename or path and not fully qualified name?
So from my pov while I testet HTML files with <style> tag (formatting as shown), inline style (no formatting which is correct), in css and scss file, it looks good.
I confirm that there is no exception been thrown and I could register app servers without problems.

@hectorespert that at the end is intended to replace GA and travis  to check for PR ?

I would suggest removing the content of the Jenkinsfile.groovy and make it call a new libraries (example here:
https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/master/nbbuild/jenkins/Jenkinsfile.groovy)

And you can add the real content here.
https://github.com/apache/netbeans-jenkins-lib/tree/master/vars

That may allow "independent" tweaking of the job and may save your time adjusting.

Libraries are for sharing Pipeline script across projects. I would especially warn against loading a library from an implicit `master` branch as it means that pushes to another repo could cause builds to suddenly start breaking in this one, or conversely that PRs to this repo would fail until another repo was updated. Better to keep the Pipeline script here, so that for example a refactoring to `build.xml` to change Ant target names could simply make the corresponding change to `Jenkinsfile`.
@matthiasblaesing  @jlahoda, can we merge this. And later make UI improvement or the current is not usable.

I see, on the particular case of netbeans I used it to avoid always  copying pipeline modification because we build release branch to have javadoc menu updated on prior release (for forward navigation). 
But for PR seems more tricky.

> @hectorespert that at the end is intended to replace GA and travis to check for PR ?

Yes, it was a try to start replacing GA and Travis due the limitations of these.

To reduce the confusion, I would like to close this PR and replaced with a "clean" PR  (see https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/3074) which can be used going forward.

If this is acceptable, then will need the milestones, tags, labels, reviews to be addressed.
For PRs, if the Jenkins file is defined in project, it allows to adjust o improve the pipeline in an specific branch before merge it, like the travis.yaml config and GA config files.
Thank you! Test result output looks much better after this.
Is there a JIRA ticket for this?
@ebresie not yet. If it's necessary I can open a ticket.

> I think that copy on a node is not a good idea because it is not straightforward. What if you want to paste only classname, filename or path and not fully qualified name?

Then you can just edit the pasted string with the keyboard. Remember--this is just a shortcut. And we don't want to pollute the menu with dozens of options... "Copy", "Copy fully qualified name", "Copy Path" etc...

In any case, copying either the path or the fully qualified name would be strictly an improvement over the current behavior, which is to paste nothing (when pasting into a text editor).

Actually I don't like the idea hiding it behind the copy node functionality as I don't see that should be the default behaviour and so it would a hidden functionality to the user.

The only reason which speaks adding it to node copy would that actually there's no text copy action for that.

I think it's a functionality which should be visible accessible.

I agree that we should check by additional menu entries for context menu. But on the other side than there should be an additional discussion of current items need to be there as well and what's the criteria for an item to be there.

I tend to agree, that the new meu entry is sensible. I did not check this PR yet, but if copying the FQN of methods and field is not yet implemented, it would make sense to implement it also later.

IMHO arguing that "another place is possible" is not a good argument, many of the current entries in the menu could be argued identically (the whole refactoring submenu). "I have no use for it" is also not a good argument, as this is also true for existing entries, as I don't remember using the CodeFolds menu.

In the end this is a single menu entry and even if more Copy actions are added, we can trivially introduce a submenu (see refactoring). This was deemed important enough that someone bothered to create a plugin for this, pulled it through the time and now another developer looked into this and suggests to pull it into the core codebase.

Thanks for the quick check.

> Actually I don't like the idea hiding it behind the copy node functionality as I don't see that should be the default behaviour and so it would a hidden functionality to the user.

That's a good point.

> This was deemed important enough that someone bothered to create a plugin for this, pulled it through the time and now another developer looked into this and suggests to pull it into the core codebase.

If multiple people find the feature worthy of a separate menu item, then that sounds fair enough to me :-)
I applied this patch to my own IDE bulid and can confirm it fixes the problem. Thank you very much for the super-quick fix!

Thanks for revising! I tested the latest patch and it works, including with multiple selection and with both the default package and other packages.

One issue for brief discussion: the name "Copy Fully Qualified Class Name" is very long, making the context menu significantly wider (being the widest item in the menu) on Linux and Windows 10 (but probably not on MacOS). Thought it's probably the most descriptive name. I'd be inclined to keep it as it is, if no one has a better idea.

Last, before we can squash-and-merge, I think the author of the PR needs to have a proper email address publicly visible on github, which then becomes part of NetBeans repository's public history.
(Oh and do we require a JIRA ticket to be created for every PR these days? I'm not sure...)

@eirikbakke can I squash + force push or is it done during merge?

I think that having 'copy qualified name' on file node may not be the best idea. After all, project explorer view is file-oriented, not class-oriented. As someone noted, (simple) name, qualified name or file paths are valid text/plain `Transferables` for a file node. FWIW, the basic Copy should copy a filename or project-relative path to the file into `text/plain` targets, but that's out of scope here.

Also note that there may be *multiple* qualified name(s) as the file can contain nested classes, for example. Or even worse, multiple toplevel classes, which is not widely used, but valid. In this case, copy FQN on file node is not sufficient, or may be misleading (copies the 1st or public toplevel class FQN only). 

The mentioned (obsolete) plugin integrates with the Navigator (which allows to copy FQNs of individual classes based on navigator node selection) and Java Editor (which allows the same by inspecting caret position -> ElementHandle at that position). With a shortcut attached to the navigator / editor action, this could be better approach: Goto Type -> open file (caret positions) -> shortcut-copy-fqn (fqn of found class copied) -> CTRL-F4 (previous editor selects) -> paste.

The reasons are more deeper: I fear this patch will fix the profiler, but will break other code that may use e.g. system properties that contains spaces or other 'illegal' chars. As noted in [NETBEANS-5732](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-5732), the culprit is the profiler integration which quotes the output of StartupExtender, when it should not.
https://github.com/apache/netbeans-jenkins-lib/pull/31 related
should be ported to former release branches

:+1: Thanks, was just looking at similar.  Bit annoying if it's going to require porting to every release branch, though.  On the other hand, there's not much else we can do to filter out the unwanted release docs I guess?  May be useful should we want to stop publishing some docs after a time?  Maybe should drop the list of all releases in top bar?  Is that the only thing that requires old releases to need updating for changes?

backporting is not fun but I did it a few time. I perso like the up bar because it tell students that their are not up to date and allow to navigate the api diff.
But we may have other issues like jquery to be changed, or browser deprecating old html. 

I'm not sure we can stop publishing doc but, we should ensure that their is no NetBeans IDE connection to thoose page otherwise lots of 404

Good points.  Keep it simple, at least for now.

Longer term, maybe we bring the template from elsewhere (like release info) - number of branches to backport to is only going to increase! :smile:
I've changed the annotation processor as requested - now generates `.instance` files, each of them creates a `SimpleTransformationCustomizer` instance. Tests were adjusted.
Rebased on more recent master.

@ebarboni @juneau001 I have updated the PR and it seems to work as intended with GF6.1 on JDK16.

Now possible JDKs for GF 6.1 are only 1.8, 11 and 16, removed all other intermediate JDKs.
Officially only JDK 11 is supported on GF 6.1, but 16 mainly works so JDK 16 is there too.
I'm not sure if GF 6.1 works on 1.8 as it's not clear from the documentation, but included nevertheless. 

Controlled that GF 6.1 correctly launches from NetBeans running on JDK 16 with Glassfish platform set to JDK 16 and that it does not add the --add-opens to JDKs less than 9. Did not do further testing.

Unfortunately I'm away in these days, will be back with a computer the 6th of August. Basically the last two commits descrive everything.

With the domain.xml of glassfish 6.1 it is not possible to run it on JDK 8 as the add-opens calls will always clash. So I put my work where my mouth was and this is my suggestion:

https://github.com/matthiasblaesing/netbeans/tree/pr-3056

The two last commits are the suggested changes. With that applied glassfish comes up without exceptions, in contrast to the situation in this PR where exceptions are generated about inaccessibles classes. Given that the domain.xml opens more packages, than the change proposed here, this looks sane.

> I think that having 'copy qualified name' on file node may not be the best idea. After all, project explorer view is file-oriented, not class-oriented. As someone noted, (simple) name, qualified name or file paths are valid text/plain `Transferables` for a file node. FWIW, the basic Copy should copy a filename or project-relative path to the file into `text/plain` targets, but that's out of scope here.
> 
> Also note that there may be _multiple_ qualified name(s) as the file can contain nested classes, for example. Or even worse, multiple toplevel classes, which is not widely used, but valid. In this case, copy FQN on file node is not sufficient, or may be misleading (copies the 1st or public toplevel class FQN only).
> 
> The mentioned (obsolete) plugin integrates with the Navigator (which allows to copy FQNs of individual classes based on navigator node selection) and Java Editor (which allows the same by inspecting caret position -> ElementHandle at that position). With a shortcut attached to the navigator / editor action, this could be better approach: Goto Type -> open file (caret positions) -> shortcut-copy-fqn (fqn of found class copied) -> CTRL-F4 (previous editor selects) -> paste.

I slightly agree that the position in projects view might not be optimal. On the other hand I wonder if the other menu entries apply to a file only context. e.g. `Find usages` looks for class usage not for the file usage.

I fully agree that - in case a menu entry is available in editor view - it should be caret position aware as I also see the end user expectation to be that way. So I removed that entry for now.
